document.docAuthor: Murao, Ryuki, Lee, Heung-Sik & Tadauchi, Osamu
document.masterDocTitle: Bees of the Lasioglossum series (Hymenoptera: Halictidae) in South Korea, with an illustrated keys to species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Bees of the Lasioglossum series (Hymenoptera: Halictidae) in South Korea, with an illustrated keys to species

heading.emphasis:
Key to the species of the
Lasioglossum
series in South Korea

subSubSection.paragraph: 1 . Mesoscutum with anterior edge reflexed upward, medio-anterior region with punctures forming a dense transverse ridge (Fig.

2 A); T 1 basally with dense, thick tomentum (Fig. 2 B)....................
Lasioglossum subopacum subopacum (Smith)
- Mesoscutum flat and punctate on medio-anterior margin (Fig. 2 C); T 1 without tomentum (Fig. 2 D).................... 2 2 . Metapostnotum and posterior surface of propodeum demarcated by transverse carina on posterior margin of metapostnotum

(sometimes weakly so) (Fig. 2 E)......................................................................... 3 - Metapostnotum and posterior surface of propodeum demarcated by distinct oblique carina on posterior surface (Figs. 2 F, 4 D)

or not distinctly demarcated by carina (
Fig. 4
C).............................................................. 7 3 . Metapostnotum of propodeum dull, with distinct tessellation among ridges (
Fig. 3 A
).............. …
L. exiliceps (Vachal)
- Metapostnotum of propodeum shiny, nearly smooth among ridges (
Fig. 3 B
)....................................... 4 4 . Posterior surface of propodeum with complete carina extending dorsally to transverse carina (
Fig. 3
C)...................

..................................................................................
L . proximatum (Smith)
- Posterior surface of propodeum with incomplete carina not extending to transverse carina (
Fig. 3
D).................... 5 5 . Supraclypeus shiny, with very weak tessellation (
Fig. 3
E); T 1 medially with sparser PP (IS = 7 d in maximimu;
Fig. 4 A
)....

.........................................................................
L. primavera Sakagami & Maeta
- Supraclypeus dull, with distinct tessellation (
Fig. 3
F); T 1 medially with denser PP (IS = 1.5 d in maximum;
Fig. 4 B
)........

.................................................................................
L . sutshanicum Pesenko
6 . Propodeum with ratio between width of apex of oblique ridges (bidirectional arrows in
Fig. 4
C) and maximum width of poste-

rior surface 0.38–0.68 (n = 13 )........................................................................... 7 - Propodeum with ratio between width of apex of oblique ridges (bidirectional arrows in
Fig. 4
D) and maximum width of poste-

rior surface 0.05–0.2 (n = 14 )............................................................................ 9 7 . PP on T 1 basally and medially with dense PP (IS = 1–1.5 d;
Fig. 4
E)..........................
L. upinense (Morawitz)
- PP on T 1 medially sparser than that on both basally and apically (IS => 1.5 d in maximum;
Fig. 4
F).................... 8 8 . Mesoscutum and mesoscutellum mixed with dark hairs; PP on lower declivitous surface of T 1 sparser than below species (IS =

.............................................................................
L . circularum Fan & Ebmer
- Integument of mesoscutum nearly smooth; lateral and posterior surfaces of propodeum with sparse tomentose hairs....... 11 11 . Lateral and oblique carinae of posterior surface of propodeum strongly developed (
Fig. 6 A
); submedial patch of T 1 with

sparser PP (IS = 3.5 d in maximum;
Fig. 6
C).................................................
L. occidens (Smith)
- Lateral and oblique carinae of posterior surface of propodeum more weakly developed (
Fig. 6 B
); submedial patch of T 1 with

The male of
L. sutshanicum
could not examine in the present study. Therefore, it is not include in the following key.

paragraph.keyLead:
1 . Mesoscutum reflexed upward on medio-anterior margin similar to Fig. 2 A............
L. subopacum subopacum (Smith)
- Mesoscutum flat on medio-anterior margin such as Fig. 2 C.................................................... 2

2 . Mesoscutum medially and posteriorly with sparser PP (IS = 3 d in maxmimum) such as
Fig. 5
C...
L. denticolle (Morawitz)

- Mesoscutum medially and posteriorly with denser PP (IS = 1.5 d in maximum) such as
Fig. 5
D........................ 3

5 . Apical part of hair tuft on S 6 longitudinally narrow (
Fig. 7 A
)............................
L. circularum Fan & Ebmer

6 . Submedial patch of T 1 with sparser PP in both sexes (IS = 3.5 d in maximum; white circle in
Fig. 6
C)...
L. occidens (Smith)

- Submedial patch of T 1 with denser PP in both sexes (IS = 2 d in maximum; white circle in
Fig. 6
D)...
L. formosae (Strand)

7 . Hair tuft on S 6 boomerang-shaped (
Fig. 8 D
).............................................
L. upinense (Morawitz)

8 . Apical part of hair tuft on S 6 small and short (
Fig. 8 A
).........................
L. nipponicola Sakagami & Tadauchi

- Apical part of hair tuft on S 6 longitudinally elongate (
Fig. 7 D
)..............................
L. kansuense (Blüthgen)

9 . Head nearly as long as wide or slightly longer than wide (HL/HW ratio = 0.98–1.06 , n = 10 )..........
L . exiliceps (Vachal)

10 . F 2 approximately 2 × F 1 ; male genitalia with ventral retrorse lobe.............................
L . proximatum (Smith)

- F 2 approximately 1.2 × F 1 ; male genitalia without ventral retrorse lobe................
L. primavera Sakagami & Maeta
